primary_bottleneck.bottleneck: Distribution — total invisibility to target market
evidence: 0 presence on any platform where barbers make software decisions (Facebook Groups, Instagram)
0 listings on any software directory (G2, Capterra, GetApp)
SPA architecture = 0 SEO visibility (only homepage indexed)
Reddit outreach targets SaaS founders, not barbers
2,400 impressions → 17 clicks = 0.71% CTR = messaging doesn't resonate even when seen
17 clicks → 1 user = 5.9% click-to-signup = website doesn't convert
1 user → 0 paying = no revenue signal at all
primary_bottleneck.explanation: This is not a product problem (yet) — it's a distribution problem. The product exists but nobody in the target market knows about it. The founder is marketing to the wrong people (Reddit SaaS communities) on the wrong platform (Reddit instead of Facebook/Instagram) with the wrong message ('easiest booking software' instead of 'no app download needed'). Every layer of the funnel is broken: discovery, click-through, signup, and conversion.

secondary_bottleneck.bottleneck: Positioning — generic messaging in a commodity market
evidence: Homepage meta: 'Online Booking Software for Barbers & Salons' — identical to 50+ competitors
Best differentiator ('no app download for clients') is buried in Reddit comments, not on website
Brand name 'Timber' confuses with lumber industry
Selling features (booking + payments + CRM) instead of outcomes (fewer no-shows, more bookings)

whats_working.signal: Founder is actively seeking and accepting feedback
whats_working.evidence: 94 comments on Reddit post, founder responded to most, acknowledged mistakes
whats_working.leverage: This coachability is rare and valuable — the founder will likely execute on good advice

whats_working.evidence: Working signup flow, booking system, and (likely) payment processing at timberpos.app
whats_working.leverage: Having a working demo to show barbers is a significant advantage over 'coming soon' competitors

whats_working.evidence: Booking friction (forced app downloads) is confirmed by Reddit discussions and competitor reviews
whats_working.leverage: This specific pain ('my clients hate downloading apps to book') could be the entire marketing message

whats_not_working.evidence: SPA architecture prevents indexing. Only 1 page indexed. Built city/industry pages nobody can find.
whats_not_working.recommendation: Abandon SEO as a channel until SSR is implemented. Zero time should be spent on SEO content.

whats_not_working.evidence: r/SaaS is SaaS founders, not barbers. Founder's post got sympathy from devs, not customers.
whats_not_working.recommendation: Shift to Facebook barber groups and Instagram immediately

whats_not_working.evidence: 17 clicks → 1 signup = 5.9% conversion. Generic copy doesn't differentiate from competitors.
whats_not_working.recommendation: Rewrite homepage around 'no app download' differentiator with specific barber-focused language

whats_not_working.evidence: Google 'TimberPOS' returns lumber industry results. Name hurts every marketing effort.
whats_not_working.recommendation: Evaluate rebrand. Every marketing dollar invested in 'Timber' has a negative SEO externality.

awareness.benchmark: A new SaaS with active organic marketing should see 10,000-50,000 impressions/month within 3 months

interest.benchmark: Organic search CTR for position 1 is ~30%. Even position 10 is ~2.5%. 0.71% suggests either very low ranking or poor meta descriptions.
interest.gap: Messaging doesn't compel clicks even when shown

signup.benchmark: Decent SaaS landing pages convert 5-15% of visitors. 5.9% from 17 clicks is too small a sample to be meaningful.
signup.gap: Sample too small for statistical significance, but directionally weak

activation.note: Cannot assess activation quality without more user data

revenue.benchmark: After 1.5 months with a live product, 0 revenue is a yellow-to-red flag depending on pricing model and sales cycle
revenue.gap: No evidence anyone will pay for this product

overall_growth_health.interpretation: Critical. The growth engine is not running — it hasn't been built yet. There is no channel producing leads, no messaging that converts, and no evidence of willingness to pay. However, this is a common position for a solo technical founder 1.5 months in. The question isn't 'is this working?' (it's not) — it's 'can the founder shift from building to selling?' If yes, the situation is recoverable. If no, this will slowly die of obscurity.
overall_growth_health.trajectory: flat-to-declining — without a channel shift, more time will not produce different results
